newsitem.title: UK: UK's Blair - interest rate rises had been overdue.
newsitem.headline: UK's Blair - interest rate rises had been overdue.

text.p: Prime Minister Tony Blair said "serious inflationary problems" had faced the British economy as a result of the failure of the previous government to act on interest rates.
Interest rates have been raised three times since Labour swept to power in a landslide election victory on May 1 but Blair pinned the blame for the rises on the former Conservative government.

"Interest rates have gone up because of what happened a year ago, not because of what's happening now, and that is very frustrating for us," Blair told The Mirror newspaper in an interview published on Tuesday.
The Labour government has given the Bank of England independence to set interest rates, which Blair said would prevent such problems in the future.

"Interest rates have had to go up because the right decisions were not taken six or nine months ago and what is essential for the long-term strength of the country's economy is that interest rate decisions are not taken for short-term political expediency but for sound economic reasons," he added.

Blair said higher rates had to be used to "squeeze the inflation out" of the economy. He said that Labour had "solved" Britain's budget deficit problem and that the country would be out of debt in two or three years.
Base rates stand at 6.75 percent and there is speculation that they could be raised again when the Bank of England's monetary policy committee meets next month.
